title: CBI books former BCCI president Muthiah in bank fraud case
text:
NEW DELHI: Probing banking frauds involving several public sector banks and business houses/private companies, the CBI on Friday raided former BCCI president A C Muthiah after registering a case against him for an alleged bank fraud of Rs 274 crore.
Muthiah has been booked along with three directors of his First Leasing Company of India.
The CBI said a case was registered under IPC sections related to criminal conspiracy, cheating and forgery among others against Muthiah, the then chairman of First Leasing Company of India Ltd, the company, the then managing director Farouk Irani, the then senior vice-president S Dilli Raj, the then CFO L Shivaramakrishnan, and two Chennai-based chartered accountancy firms Sarathy and Balu, and M K Dandeker and Company.
The allegations including forgery, forgery for the purpose of cheating, using forged documents as genuine and falsification of accounts took place during 2005-2013.
"A case was registered on the complaint of IDBI Bank on the allegations of cheating the bank and causing an alleged loss of Rs 274 crore," CBI spokesperson Devpreet Singh said.
The agency searched eight places -- seven in Chennai and one in Hyderabad -- led to recovery of incriminating documents.
The CBI has recently accelerated its probe into banking frauds with three major cases registered within one week.
Last week, CBI raided and booked liquor baron Vijay Mallya for alleged fraud in the loan of Rs 900 crore taken from IDBI Bank.
Sources said more banks and private companies are likely to be booked soon.
It is alleged that the loans were given by public sector banks without proper verification of the companies. Several officials in public sector banks connived with private companies for their personal benefit, which caused huge losses to banks. It is believed that bad loans of some 30 public sector banks have cost several thousand crores.
